title: MUSA 5080 Portfolio
text:
This portfolio documents my learning journey in Public Policy Analytics (MUSA 5080).


Advanced spatial analysis and data science for urban planning and public policy.




Weekly Notes: My learning reflections and key concepts
Labs: Completed assignments and analyses
Final Project: Capstone modeling challenge




My name is Zheng Qianmu, and I come from an urban and rural planning background. I am currently a MUSA student. My email address is zheng21@upenn.edu, and my GitHub username is xqdqc_hub. I am taking this course to learn R, a highly powerful data analysis tool. Through friends in urban management studies, I have learned that quantitative analysis in public policy is a crucial component of both academic research and government work. I hope to gain relevant knowledge and have the opportunity to participate in a comprehensive policy analysis project.




Email: zheng21@upenn.edu
GitHub: @xqdqc_hub

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Coding Techniques

Some basic methods for data processing in R, such as how to import libraries, and how to use functions like select/filter/mutate/summarize to manipulate data tables.

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Questions & Challenges

I still donâ€™t fully understand the specific functions and usage of Quarto.
I need more practice with the meaning, usage, and code uploading methods across various GitHub interfaces.

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Connections to Policy

The basic methods and workflows for data processing in R learned in this lesson lay a foundation for future statistical data analysis. We can use these fundamental techniques to handle missing or duplicate data, as well as perform data filtering and merging, before proceeding with further policy analysis.

title: Week 1 Notes - Course Introduction
text:
Reflection

The most interesting part was being introduced to the concept of dataframes in R. Although similar to Python, operations like creating columns are more convenient to use, which makes me want to use R more often for data processing and analysis in the future.
